Key Arguments: The bill infringes on freedom of speech by creating two classes of citizens with different rights to spread information.
The Internet is a democratic tool that should not be restricted by excessive fines and industry-wide codes.
Determining what is true or false is challenging due to the evolving nature of information.
The bill could lead to anti-competitive practices by allowing larger digital services to create onerous codes.
The extraterritorial applicability of the bill is impractical and overreaching.
The bill does not learn from the flaws of the News Media Bargaining Code (NMBC).
The bill could damage trust and community values by encouraging citizens to report on each other.
Notable Quotes: It is disheartening to see that the existence of this bill reflects a lack of respect for the freedom of speech of Australian citizens.
The Internet is a groundbreaking democratic invention that has given a voice to ordinary people.
Implementing industry or mandatory codes to remove content based on such fluid criteria would stifle open and honest discussions.
The proposed bill empowers industry bodies to create industry codes that can become anti-competitive wedges.
